## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 388, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 7 Probability & Statistics 2 (S2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 415, 390, 433]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 446, 782, 463]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 463, 324, 478]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 478, 504, 494]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 494, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 509, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 539, 910, 570]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 910, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 600, 598, 615]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 615, 606, 630]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 644, 608, 660]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 660, 757, 676]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 676, 440, 691]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The times, in minutes, taken by competitors to complete a puzzle have mean \(\mu\) and standard deviation 3. The times taken by a random sample of 10 competitors are noted and the results are given below.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 114, 826, 133]]<|/det|>
25.2 26.8 18.5 25.5 30.1 28.9 27.0 26.1 26.0 24.9

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 152, 154, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 152, 747, 170]]<|/det|>
Stating a necessary assumption, calculate a \(97\%\) confidence interval for \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
A train company claims that \(92\%\) of trains on a particular line arrive on time. Sanjeep suspects that the true percentage is less than \(92\%\). He chooses a random sample of 20 trains on this line and finds that exactly 16 of them arrive on time. Making an assumption that should be stated, test at the \(5\%\) significance level whether Sanjeep's suspicion is justified. [6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 73, 156, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{B}(300, 0.01)\). Use a Poisson approximation to find \(\mathrm{P}(2 < X < 6)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 560, 191, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 560, 826, 581]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(Y\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(\lambda)\), and \(\mathrm{P}(Y = 0) = \mathrm{P}(Y = 2)\). Find \(\lambda\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 560, 920, 579]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 917, 92]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(Z\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(5.2)\) and it is given that \(\mathrm{P}(Z = n) < \mathrm{P}(Z = n + 1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 98, 185, 117]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 98, 443, 117]]<|/det|>
Write down an inequality in \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 98, 920, 117]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 336, 225, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 336, 636, 355]]<|/det|>
Hence or otherwise find the largest possible value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 336, 922, 355]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 618, 92]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(X\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 98, 631, 136]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}k(3x - x^{2}) & 0\leqslant x\leqslant 3,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}. \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 156, 156, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 155, 292, 175]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = \frac{2}{9}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 156, 920, 175]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 495, 176, 514]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 495, 311, 514]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(1 \leqslant X \leqslant 2)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 496, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
Bob is a self-employed builder. In the past his weekly income had mean \(\)546\(and standard deviation\) \ \(120\) . Following a change in Bob's working pattern, his mean weekly income for 40 randomly chosen weeks was \(\)581. You should assume that the standard deviation remains unchanged at \(\)120.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 134, 838, 153]]<|/det|>
Test at the \(2.5\%\) significance level whether Bob's mean weekly income has increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Bob finds his mean weekly income for another random sample of 40 weeks and carries out a similar test at the \(2.5\%\) significance level.
